definition: a database operation that either updates an existing record or inserts a new record into a table, depending on whether a matching record already exists

benefits.name: efficiency
benefits.discussion: It's faster and cheaper than performing separate "check then insert/update" operations, especially for large datasets

benefits.name: atomicity
benefits.discussion: the operation is atomic, meaning it's treated as a single, indivisible transaction

benefits.name: data consistency
benefits.discussion: essential for managing data that might arrive out of order or for correcting errors, ensuring the database remains consistent

definition: an RDF query language able to retrieve and manipulate data stored in Resource Description Framework format
storage engine for MySQL and MariaDB databases, known for its reliability and performance in handling large databases and complex web applications
notes: the default storage engine in MySQL since version 5.5.5
it offers ACID-compliant transaction support, including features like atomicity, consistency, isolation, and durability

definition: essentially a persistent object store for software written in an object-oriented programming language with an application programming interface API for storing and retrieving objects, and little or no specific support for querying
a database management system (DBMS) similar to a relational database, but with an object-oriented database model
notes: provides a middle ground between relational databases and object-oriented databases
